subject: Re: [junit] Is it worth writing test cases for this sort of scenario?
msgSnippet: Long dependency chains are best broken up by substituting the dependees with dummy or mock objects in the tests. See:
messageBody:
Long dependency chains are best broken up by substituting the dependees with
dummy or mock objects in the tests. See:
http://www.sidewize.com/company/mockobjects.pdf
and
http://www.objectmentor.com/publications/DesignPrin.pdf
for examples and general pronciples.

Johannes Link

----- Original Message -----
> I am feeling that it is difficult to write, because we need to process
> all objects to reach object d. There is lot of dependencies between the
> classes.
>
> In one place it is creating objects. How to write test case to verify
> that created object is wrong or right?
>
> In run time they are writing data into database, passing to various
> objects. We need to write test cases for all these. Creating objects and
> so on. Is it worth writing test cases for this sort of scenario? I am
> thinking that doing black box testing is better than writing JUnit test
> cases.
